questions.text: Which of the following is considered a type of mechanical ventilation?
questions.explanation:
Types of Ventilation

Natural (Option B, C and D)

Mechanical (Option A )

1. Wind:

  • Perflation: wind blows through a room
  • Aspiration: wind bypasses and exerts a suction
  • Cross-ventilation.

2. Diffusion: Air passes through small openings

3. Temperature Inequality: Air movement from high to low density due to temperature difference.

1. Exhaust: air is extracted outside by exhaust fans

2. Plenum: fresh air blown inside by centrifugal fans

3. Balanced: Combination of exhaust and plenum

4. Air conditioning: control of all air factors affecting physical and chemical conditions of the atmosphere

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. He reports severe ankle pain and is unable to bear weight. X-rays reveal a fracture in the neck of the talus, and is shown below. Based on Hawkin's classification, which type of fracture does this represent?
questions.explanation:
Type I (Option A)

Undisplaced vertical fracture neck of talus

Type II (Option B)

Displaced fracture neck + Subluxation or dislocation of subtalar joint

Type III (Option C)

Displaced fracture neck + Dislocation of the body of the talus from both ankle and subtalar joints

Type IV (Option D)

Displaced fracture neck + Dislocation of the head and body of the talus from subtalar/ankle/talonavicular joints

Undisplaced Fracture

Displaced Fracture
  • Conservative treatment
  • Below-knee plaster cast
  • For 8-10 weeks
  • Closed reduction by traction in plantar flexion and a plaster cast is put in equinus.
  • If it fails, ORIF with lag screws is done.
  • Sometimes Herbert bone screw is used:
    • Headless compression screw
    • Generally not removed

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department after an accidental chemical exposure to his eyes while working in a lab. He reports immediate burning and decreased vision. Upon examination, there is corneal epithelial loss and conjunctival swelling. What is the most appropriate immediate management step?

options.label: A
options.text: Necrotic tissue removal and administer topical antibiotics

options.label: C
options.text: Immediate irrigation with water or saline for 20-30 minutes

questions.correct_answer: C. Immediate irrigation with water or saline for 20-30 minutes
questions.explanation:
Chemical Injuries

Description

Chemical eye injuries are caused by acidic or alkaline substances entering the eye (accidental or due to assault), presenting a severe ocular emergency that demands immediate treatment.

Cause

Alkali burn (most common, more severe)

  • Ammonia (most common), NaOH (sodium hydroxide), lime [CaO].

Acid (coagulates the surface proteins)

  • Hydrofluoric acid (used in glass etching), sulphuric acid
 

Others: Detergents, cosmetics, fertilizers, insecticides, etc.

Pathophysiology

 

Management

Immediate management:

  • The first and the most crucial step while treating a chemical injury is copious irrigation (water or saline for at least 20-30 minutes or until the eye’s pH is restored) by double eversion of the lid. (Option C)
  • Debridement: Carefully excise dead conjunctiva and corneal epithelium using a cotton swab.(Option A ruled out)
 

Medical management:

  • Antibiotics (Option A ruled out)
  • Cycloplegics (relax the ciliary muscle),
  • Steroids only for an initial 7 days (as they reduce collagen synthesis and impair healing). (Option B ruled out)
  • Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) 10% E/D 2hrly. (promotes collagen synthesis and improves wound healing)
  • Citrate 10% E/D 2 hourly for ten days (controls inflammation and inhibits collagenase)
  • Tetracycline (collagenase inhibitor)
  • Acetylcysteine 10% (anti-collagenase)
 

Surgical management

  • Early: Advancement of tenon capsule, limbal cell transplantation, amniotic membrane grafting
  • Late:
    • Symblepharon: Division of bands in Symblepharon, conjunctival grafting, mucous membrane grafting
    • Limbal cells: Advancement of tenon capsule, limbal cell transplantation, amniotic membrane grafting.

Complications
  • Secondary glaucoma
  • Limbal stem cell deficiency
  • Pseudopterygium
  • Corneal opacity (keratoplasty or keratoprosthesis). (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: In a histopathological examination of a lung biopsy from a patient with suspected sarcoidosis, which of the following microscopic features would be most characteristic and supportive of the diagnosis?

He also reports joint stiffness and pain, as well as type 2 diabetes mellitus. On examination, the patient appears older than his stated age, with characteristic "bird-like" facies and a high-pitched voice. Which of the following conditions is most likely to be associated with his presentation?

options.label: D

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with no medical comorbidities complaints of involuntary leakage of urine primarily when she coughs or sneezes. She has tried Kegel exercises, lifestyle modifications, such as avoiding caffeine, and pessary but these have not significantly improved her symptoms. What would be the most appropriate next step in the management of her condition?
questions.explanation:
Type of urinary Incontinence

Stress urinary Incontinence

Urgency urinary Incontinence

Overflow Incontinence

Step 1
  • Lifestyle
  • Weight loss in obese individuals
  • Reduce fluid and caffeine intake
  • Avoiding bladder irritants (e.g., caffeine, alcohol, carbonated drinks)
  • Restrict intake of fluid to 1 liter/day

If non-obstructive pathology

  • Continuous catheter drainage
  • Intermittent self-catheterization

Step 2
  • Pelvic floor muscle training( Kegel exercises)
  • Biofeedback therapy
  • Scheduled Voiding
  • Bladder retraining
  • Scheduled voiding

If obstructive pathology

  • Alpha-blockers (tamsulosin for bladder outlet obstruction)
  • Urethroplasty for urethral strictures

Step 3

Medical Treatment

  • Estrogen
  • Sympathomimetic drugs (α-adrenergic) Imipramine

Medical Treatment

  • Anticholinergics:
  1. Oxybutynin
  2. Tolterodine
  3. Fesoterodine fumarate
  4. Darifenacin
  • Beta -3 adrenergic agonist (Mirabegron* )
  • Tricyclic antidepressants (e.g., imipramine)
  

Step 4

Devices

  • Pessary
  • Urethral Inserts

Neuromodulation

  • Sacral nerve stimulation
  • Peripheral tibial nerve stimulation

Intradetrusor botulinum toxin A injection

 

  

Step 5

Surgical Treatment

  • Colposuspension
  • Midurethral tape

Tension-free vaginal tape (TVT)

Transobturator tape (TOT)

  • Microslings
  • Bladder neck suspension
  • Bulking agents injection
  • Others

Marshall-Marchetti-Krantz (MMK)

Paravaginal repair

Surgical Treatment

  • Cystoplasty (to increase bladder capacity)
  • Urinary diversion procedures (eg. ileal conduit)

questions.text: A mother brings her apparently normal 20-day-old newborn to the pediatric clinic with a complaint of milk coming through the nasal passages of the baby during feeding. Upon examination, you find the following: This condition is due to the failure of which of the following processes during embryonic development?

options.label: A
options.text: Fusion of the maxillary and medial nasal processes

options.label: B
options.text: Formation of the lateral palatine processes

questions.correct_answer: C. Fusion of the palatal shelves

questions.text: Which of the following is an indication for pregnancy termination under the eugenic grounds of the MTP Act?
questions.explanation:
Indications for MTP

Therapeutic

(Options A and B ruled out)

Pregnancy that endangers the woman's life or may cause severe physical/mental injury (e.g., cardiac disease, hypertension, epilepsy, intractable hyperemesis gravidarum, breast/ cervical cancer).

Eugenic

(Option C)

Risk of serious physical or mental abnormalities in the fetus (e.g., exposure to teratogenic drugs, infections like rubella, structural abnormalities like anencephaly).

Socio-economic

Unplanned pregnancies in low socio-economic conditions or failure of contraception.

Humanitarian

(Option D ruled out)

Pregnancy resulting from rape.

questions.text: A 45 y/o male undergoes abdominal surgery and requires fluid replacement. The patient has a history of chronic kidney disease. Which of the following fluids is most appropriate for maintenance during surgery to avoid the risk of hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis?

A 50-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with recurrent episodes of chest pain radiating to her left arm and jaw that occur at rest and are not triggered by physical exertion. ECG during an episode shows transient ST-segment elevation. Troponin levels are normal. Which type of angina is most likely responsible for her symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Stable Angina (Option A)

Prinzmetal variant angina

Unstable or crescendo angina (Option B)

Occurs

During physical exertion and emotional stress due to ↑ myocardial demands.

Episodic myocardial ischemia occurs at rest, not related to physical exertion.

The pattern of increasingly frequent, prolonged, or severe angina occurring at rest or with minimal exertion.

Associated with

Chronic stenosis of coronary arteries due to underlying atherosclerosis.

Episodic coronary vasospasm.

ECG may show transient ST-segment elevation during attacks.

Plaque disruption and increased risk of myocardial infarction.

Response to vasodilators

Responds well.

Responds well.

Need immediate medical intervention.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male presents to the clinic with worsening dyspnea on exertion, fatigue, and ankle swelling. He has a past medical history of chronic heart failure, which was diagnosed 5 years ago. Despite being on several medications, he continues to experience symptoms. On examination, his heart rate is irregular and there is evidence of jugular venous distension. What is the drug of choice for managing his condition?

A biopsy of the mass shows Mikulicz cells and is positive for Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis . What is the most appropriate treatment strategy for this patient?

options.label: A

questions.text: A 68-year-old male with type 2 diabetes mellitus managed on metformin presents to the clinic with increased blood glucose levels. Routine investigations revealed haemoglobin of 11 g/dL, serum creatinine of 2.3, and an estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) of 30 mL/min/1.73 m 2 . Which of the following additional medications can be safely prescribed to this patient?
questions.explanation:
MOA
  • Increase Incretin Levels: Prevents degradation of incretin hormones (GLP-1 and GIP)
  • Enhance Insulin Secretion from the pancreas in response to meals. (no risk of hypoglycemia)
  • Reduce Glucagon Secretion
  • Maintain neutral weight

Uses
  • Oral hypoglycemic drug (type-2 diabetes)

Drugs
  1. Linagliptin: Safe in renal failure
  2. Teneligliptin: Safe in renal failure
  3. Vildagliptin: Hepatotoxic
  4. Alogliptin
  5. Sitagliptin
  6. Saxagliptin: (Option B)
    1. Metabolised by CYP3A4, it has more drug interactions.
    2. Requires dose adjustment in renal impairment.
    3. Risk of congestive heart failure.

Side effects
  • Nausea and vomiting (most common)
  • Pancreatitis (lesser than GLP-1)
  • Risk of pancreatic and thyroid cancer (lesser than GLP-1)
  • Arthritis, Nasopharyngitis:
    • Increase interleukins and cytokines levels (similar structure to CD26)
  • Hypersensitivity reactions: Steven-Johnson syndrome, angioedema

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents with persistent knee pain and swelling of two months duration. The pain is severe at night and not relieved by NSAIDs. A biopsy was performed, and it showed pleomorphism, large hyperchromatic nuclei, and bizarre giant cells producing unmineralised osteoid. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency room after a motor vehicle accident. He displays significant behavioral changes including placing non-food objects in his mouth, increased sexual advances towards staff, and appears to have no fear when approached by the medical team. Which of the following brain structures is MOST likely to be damaged in this patient?

A 48-year-old male with small cell carcinoma of the lung presents with cyanosis of the neck and face, epistaxis, headache, dizziness and swelling over the face, neck and upper chest. He is irregular regarding chemotherapy sessions. Chest x-ray revealed a widening of the superior mediastinum. What is the investigation of choice in this condition?

A newborn is examined shortly after delivery. The physician observes a localized swelling on the baby’s head that appears several hours after birth. The swelling is confined to one side of the skull, is firm to the touch, and does not cross the suture lines. What is the most likely diagnosis for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Feature

 Cephalohematoma

Caput Succedaneum (Option A)

Definition

Blood collection between the periosteum and skull due to a ruptured emissary vein, often from trauma (e.g., forceps delivery).

Swelling from fluid accumulation between scalp layers, typically from prolonged pressure (e.g., during labor).

Situation

Generally unilateral, commonly over the parietal bone.

Can be bilateral, covering a broader area of the scalp.

Impulse on Crying

(Seen in hydrocephalus)

No impulse seen.

No impulse seen.

Limitation by Suture Line

Confined by sutures.

No restriction by sutures.

Underlying Pathology

May involve a skull fracture.

Non-pathological; usually harmless.

Occurrence

Does not appear at birth, and usually develops later.

Present at birth.

Development and Disappearance

Appears 12–24 hours after birth, and resolves in 6–8 weeks. Maybe followed by jaundice.

Disappears on its own within 24 hours. Maybe followed by jaundice.

Medico-Legal Importance

Can assist in determining how long the infant survived post-birth based on regression.

Provides clear evidence of in-utero life, though, in prolonged labor, fetal death may occur before birth.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient is admitted to the hospital with high fever, chills, and severe headache. Upon examination and laboratory tests, he is diagnosed with P.falciparum malaria. The patient's medical history reveals that he has schizophrenia and is currently on antipsychotic medication. Considering the patient's medical history, which of the following antimalarial treatments is contraindicated for this patient?
questions.explanation:
ANTI-MALARIAL DRUGS

Drug Class

Mechanism of Action

Drugs & Indications

Notes

Chloroquine Group

Inhibits the conversion of hemoglobin to hemozoin in parasites

Chloroquine: Treatment of malaria (clinical cure), lepra reaction, atopic dermatitis

 

Amodiaquine and Piperaquine: Treatment of malaria.

Chloroquine can cause ocular toxicity, including bull's eye maculopathy, anterior subcapsular cataracts, and vortex keratopathy.

Artemisinin Group

Forms free radicals that damage parasite proteins and DNA

Artesunate: Treatment of malaria (clinical cure), including complicated malaria (IV administration).

 

Artemether, Arteether, and Arterolane: Treatment of malaria (clinical cure).

Artemisinin is obtained from the Chinese herb Artesuna annua.

Quinoline

Blocks potassium channels in parasites, leading to paralysis

Quinine: Treatment of malaria (clinical cure), including complicated malaria (IV administration).

 

Quinidine: Treatment of malaria (clinical cure) and used as a Class IA antiarrhythmic drug.

Quinine is obtained from the cinchona plant and can cause ototoxicity (cinchonism), hypoglycemia, QT prolongation, hypotension, and diarrhea.

Primaquine

Disrupts the parasite's electron transport chain

Radical cure of malaria caused by P. vivax and P. ovale (targets hypnozoites).

Primaquine is not effective against erythrocytic schizogony and, therefore not used for clinical cure.

Antifolates

Inhibit dihydrofolate reductase, essential for parasite folate synthesis

Pyrimethamine and Sulfadoxine: Treatment of malaria (clinical cure), typically in combination with artesunate.

 

Proguanil: Treatment of malaria (clinical cure) and prophylaxis.

 

Sulfadoxine: Treatment of malaria

Typically in combination with artesunate.

These drugs should be combined with folinic acid (tetrahydrofolate) to prevent megaloblastic anemia.

Antibiotics

Various mechanisms targeting parasite protein synthesis

Doxycycline: Treatment of malaria (clinical cure and causal prophylaxis), pneumocystis pneumonia (in combination with primaquine).

 

Clindamycin: Treatment of malaria (clinical cure), pneumocystis pneumonia (in combination with primaquine), toxoplasmosis.

Doxycycline is C/I in pregnancy and children <8 years old.

Others

  

Mefloquine: Treatment of malaria (clinical cure and suppressive prophylaxis), particularly chloroquine-resistant strains.

 

Lumefantrine: Treatment of malaria (clinical cure), particularly with artemether in northeastern Indian states.

 

Tafenoquine: Radical cure of malaria caused by P. vivax and P. ovale.

 

Atovaquone: Treatment of malaria (clinical cure) and pneumocystis pneumonia (in combination with dapsone).

Mefloquine has a high risk of neuropsychiatric symptoms and is C/I in cerebral malaria.

Lumefantrine can cause QT prolongation.

questions.text: During the third week of gestation, the formation of the primitive streak signifies the start of gastrulation. Which statement about the primitive streak accurately describes this process?

options.label: C
options.text: It develops into the prechordal plate, defining the head-tail axis.

options.text: It originates from trophoblast cells, contributing to the amniotic cavity and yolk sac formation.

questions.correct_answer: B. It appears dorsally, becoming linear and marking the transition to a trilaminar disc.

questions.text: A 9-month-old infant is brought to the clinic with ongoing tearing and discharge from the right eye. Despite regular lacrimal sac massage and topical antibiotics, the symptoms persist. What is the next best step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Continue lacrimal sac massage and antibiotics

questions.correct_answer: B. Probing of the nasolacrimal duct
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Definition

Blockage of the nasolacrimal duct, usually at the valve of Hasner

Typical Age

Present from birth or early infancy

Symptoms

• Chronic tearing (epiphora)

• Discharge

• Recurrent conjunctivitis

First-Line Management

• Crigler massage to open the duct

• Topical antibiotics for infection

Indications for Probing

• Persistence beyond 6–10 months

• Repeated infections or failure of conservative therapy

Prognosis with Probing

>90% success if performed before 12–15 months

questions.text: Carlos, a 40-year-old father and avid hiker, arrives at the emergency department after being bitten by a stray dog on his forearm while out on a rural trail. The bite is deep enough that it has broken the skin, causing some bleeding. Carlos mentions he's never received a rabies vaccination before and is anxious about the possibility of infection. What is the most appropriate next step in managing Carlos’s injury?

options.label: A
options.text: Clean the wound and reassure Carlos that no further treatment is necessary.

options.label: B
options.text: Clean the wound and administer a series of rabies vaccines on Days 0, 3, 7, and 14, without giving Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG).

options.label: C
options.text: Thoroughly wash the wound, administer rabies vaccines on Days 0, 3, 7, and 14, and provide Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG) around the wound site.

options.label: D
options.text: Give Carlos a single dose of rabies vaccine and Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG) for rapid immunity.

questions.correct_answer: C. Thoroughly wash the wound, administer rabies vaccines on Days 0, 3, 7, and 14, and provide Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG) around the wound site.
questions.explanation:
Category

Exposure Type

Management

Category I

  • Touching or feeding animals

  • Licking of intact skin

  • Ensure proper hygiene

  • No treatment required

Category II

  • Nibbling on uncovered skin

  • Minor scratches or abrasions without bleeding

  • Immediate wound washing with soap and water

  • Rabies vaccination:

    • Unvaccinated: Days 0, 3, 7, and 14

    • Previously vaccinated: Booster doses on Days 0 and 3

    • No Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG) required

Category III

  • Bites or scratches with bleeding

  • Licks on broken skin

  • Exposure to mucous membranes (mouth, eyes, nose)

  • Immediate wound washing with soap and water, flush for at least 15 minutes.

  • Suture: Do not suture the wound immediately, as it may spread the virus, instead delay it for 24 to 48 hours.

  • Rabies vaccination:

    • Unvaccinated: Full PEP series on Days 0, 3, 7, and 14

    • Previously vaccinated: Booster doses on Days 0 and 3

 

  • Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG):

    • Equine immunoglobulin or ERIG
    • Human rabies Immunoglobulin or HRIG
      • Preferred (free from the danger of sensitisation, HIV and hepatitis viruses)
      • Dose: – 40 IU / kg IM
      • Started on Day 0 along with vaccination (can be given up to 7 days).
      • 70% is given around the wound and, the rest is given distant from the wound.

  • Required for unvaccinated individuals

  • Not needed for previously vaccinated individuals

questions.text: Match the type of cyst with the correct description of it. Types of Cysts Description 1. Functional cyst A. A mucus-filled cyst on the cervix 2. Gartner’s cyst B. Forms due to remnants of the Wolffian duct 3. Skene’s cyst C. Located near the urethra in females 4. Nabothian cyst D. Commonly occurs in the ovaries
questions.explanation:
Type of Cyst

Description

Details

Functional Cyst

Fluid-filled sacs that form on the ovaries, typically during the menstrual cycle.

 

 
  •  2 Types:
    1. Follicular cysts form due to hormonal dysfunction prior to ovulation, leading to expansion of the follicular antrum with serous fluid.
    2. Corpus luteum cysts form due to excessive hemorrhage from the vascular corpus luteum following ovulation.
  • High-dose combination oral contraceptives (COCs) suppress ovarian activity and protect against cyst development.
  • Surgical excision is considered for large, persistent cysts or smaller ones causing persistent symptoms. Usually benign and not cancerous.

Gartner’s Cyst

Forms from remnants of the Wolffian duct
  • Located along vaginal walls
  • Can cause discomfort, urinary issues, or dyspareunia if large
  • Treatment may involve surgical removal if symptomatic

Skene’s Cyst

Located near the urethra in females, formed from the Skene’s glands.
  • Involved in lubrication of the urethral opening. Usually presents as a urethral diverticulum.
  • Cysts here can cause urinary problems, pain, or discomfort.
  • Treatment may include antibiotics for infection or surgical drainage/removal if necessary.

Nabothian Cyst

Mucus-filled cysts that occur on the cervix.
  • Form when mucus-producing glands in the cervix are covered by skin cells, trapping the mucus.
  • Generally harmless, asymptomatic and often found during routine pelvic exams.
  • No treatment is typically required unless they cause significant symptoms, in which case they can be drained or removed.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, who gave birth 3 months ago, presents with symptoms of anxiety, palpitations, and weight loss. Her thyroid function tests reveal abnormalities. What is the most likely phase of postpartum thyroiditis she is experiencing?
questions.explanation:
Definition

Postpartum thyroiditis is an inflammation of the thyroid gland that occurs after childbirth, typically within the first year postpartum

Etiology
  • Autoimmune Factors:
    Autoimmune Thyroiditis: Postpartum thyroiditis is often an autoimmune condition, characterized by the presence of thyroid autoantibodies (e.g., anti-thyroid peroxidase (anti-TPO) antibodies).
    Immune Rebound: After childbirth, the immune system rebounds from the immunosuppressed state of pregnancy, which can trigger an autoimmune attack on the thyroid.
  • Genetic Predisposition
  • Hormonal Changes

Clinical manifestations

It has 2 phases which has a clinical progression-

Thyrotoxic phase( 1-4 months) (Option A)

Hypothyroid phase( 4 to 8 months) (Option B)

The hypothyroid phase either leads to euthyroid phase (Option C) or permanent hypothyroidism (Option D).

Investigation

Thyroid Function Tests:

  • TSH: Elevated in the hypothyroid phase, suppressed in the hyperthyroid phase.
  • Free T4: Elevated in the hyperthyroid phase, decreased in the hypothyroid phase.
  • Free T3: May also be elevated in the hyperthyroid phase.

Thyroid Antibodies:

  • Anti-thyroid Peroxidase (Anti-TPO) Antibodies: Often elevated, indicating an autoimmune component.

Treatment:
  1. Hyperthyroid phase- Beta blockers
  2. Hypothyroid phase- Levothyroxine, (25 mcg to 75 mcg)

Regular monitoring and long term follow up of the thyroid profile.

questions.text: A 32 y/o woman at 12 weeks gestation with a history of mitral valve prolapse denies chest pain, shortness of breath, and syncope. What is her prognosis for this pregnancy?

options.label: A
options.text: Good prognosis with minimal risk of complications.

options.label: B
options.text: Poor prognosis with a high risk of heart failure.

options.label: C
options.text: Moderate prognosis with potential for arrhythmias.

questions.correct_answer: A. Good prognosis with minimal risk of complications.
questions.explanation:
Prognosis

Heart Condition

Good prognosis with minimal complications
(Option A)
  • Mitral valve prolapse without pathological myxomatous degeneration.
  • Small to moderate-sized ventricular septal defects (VSDs).
  • Repaired transposition of the great vessels.
  • Atrial septal defect (ASD) unless pulmonary hypertension has developed.
  • Mild MS and AS.

Poor prognosis with high risk of heart failure.

(Option B)
  • Eisenmenger syndrome.
  • Severe aortic stenosis.
  • Severe coarctation of the aorta.
  • Uncorrected Cyanotic Heart Disease.
  • Idiopathic pulmonary arterial hypertension.
  • Prior myocardial infarction, especially with diabetes-associated ischemic heart disease.
  • Marfan Syndrome with Aortic Root Dilation

Moderate prognosis with potential for arrhythmias.

(Option C)

  • Dilated Cardiomyopathy
  • Mitral stenosis.
  • Arrhythmogenic right ventricular dysplasia.

Uncertain prognosis requiring frequent monitoring (Option D)

  • Mechanical heart valve.

questions.text: Match the following genes involved in the development of depression with their normal functions. Genes Encoded for A) SLC6A4 i) Serotonin receptor B) DRD4 ii) Dopamine transporter C) HTR1A iii) Serotonin transporter D) SLC6A3 iv) Dopamine receptor
questions.explanation:
Genetic Influence
  • About one-third of major depression risk is attributed to genetic factors.
  • The gene encoding of serotonin receptor: HTR1A
  • The gene for serotonin transporter: 5HTTP/SLC6A4
  • The gene for dopamine receptor: DRD4
  • The gene for dopamine transporter: SLC6A3

Family History
  • Risk increases 2.5–3 times if a first-degree relative has depression.
  • Life events can raise risk from 5 to 16 times shortly after occurrence.

Neurobiological Mechanisms

Studies show that individuals with the short allele of 5-HTTLPR (serotonin transporter gene) exhibit amygdala hyperreactivity to emotional threats

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of mild lower abdominal pain and vaginal spotting. She has a history of 6 weeks of amenorrhea. On examination, she is hemodynamically stable, and a transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) reveals an adnexal mass of 3cm consistent with an unruptured ectopic pregnancy. No fetal cardiac activity is found. Her initial beta hCG level is measured at 2,000 IU/L. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Management

Criteria/Indication

Description

Expectant Management
  • Beta hCG < 1,500 IU/L
  • No significant symptoms
  • Strong likelihood of spontaneous resolution
  • Monitoring without intervention, relying on the natural resolution of the ectopic pregnancy

Medical Management
  • Beta hCG < 3,000 IU/L
  • Adnexal mass < 4 cm
  • No fetal cardiac activity
  • Hemodynamically stable
  • Methotrexate (single dose/ multi-dose regimen) (best)
  • KCl (directly in sac)
  • Mifepristone
  • Prostaglandins

Surgical Management
  • Beta hCG > 5,000 IU/L
  • Size of ectopic > 4 cm
  • Presence of cardiac activity
  • Linear Salpingostomy (best)
  • Resection Anastomosis

questions.text: A 3-y/o child is brought to the emergency department with symptoms of severe fatigue, vomiting, and episodes of hypoglycemia. Blood tests reveal low glucose levels without elevated ketone bodies, as indicated by a negative Rothera and Benedict tests. Further examination indicates a fatty liver. The child's mother gives h/o acute fatty liver during her pregnancy with the child. Which of the following deficiencies is most likely responsible for these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
FATTY ACID OXIDATION DEFECTS

CONGENITAL DEFECTS

ACQUIRED DEFECTS

1. CPT-I Deficiency:

  • Site: Liver
  • Pathophysiology: Leading to decreased fatty acid oxidation and ketogenesis, which can result in hypoglycemia (Option A ruled out)
 

2. CPT-II Deficiency:

  • Site: Primarily affecting skeletal muscle and potentially the liver in severe cases
 

3. Defects in β-oxidation Enzymes: 2 types:

 
  • Long and Short-Chain 3-Hydroxyacyl-CoA Dehydrogenase Deficiency: Can cause nonketotic hypoglycemia, coma, and fatty liver. May also contribute to acute fatty liver during pregnancy
 
  • 3-Ketoacyl-CoA Thiolase and HMG-CoA Lyase Deficiency: These deficiencies not only disrupt fatty acid oxidation but also affect the breakdown of leucine, a ketogenic amino acid.

1. Carnitine Deficiency:

  • Common in preterm babies
  • Cause:
    • Inadequate biosynthesis or renal leakage.
    • Hemolysis
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Impaired fatty acid oxidation→hypoglycemia & Lipid accumulation→muscular weakness (Option D ruled out)
 

2. Jamaican Vomiting Sickness:

 
  • Cause: Consuming unripe ackee fruit containing the toxin hypoglycin,
  • Pathophysiology: This condition inhibits medium- and short-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase, leading to hypoglycemia (Option C ruled out)

CLINICAL FEATURES
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Nonketotic Hypoglycemia
  • Lipid Accumulation
  • Dicarboxylic Aciduria
    • Marked by the excretion of C6—C10 ω-dicarboxylic acids and non-ketotic hypoglycemia
    • It arises from a lack of mitochondrial medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase.
  • Muscular Weakness due to the buildup of lipids in muscles
  • Coma
  • Fatty Liver
  • Acute Fatty Liver of Pregnancy: Due to Long-chain 3-hydroxyacyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency indicating a potential role of hormonal changes influencing enzyme activity.
  • Neurological Symptoms: Defects impacting fatty acid oxidation, especially those also affecting the breakdown of leucine.

questions.text: Which of the following factors are responsible for testicular descent? Testosterone Gubernaculum Intra-abdominal Pressure CGRP (Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide) INSL3 (Insulin-like 3) Processus Vaginalis
questions.explanation:
Factor

Role in Testicular Descent

Testosterone

Stimulates gubernaculum shortening, guiding the testes into the scrotum.

Gubernaculum

A ligament that pulls the testes down during descent.

Intra-abdominal Pressure

Helps push the testes through the inguinal canal.

CGRP (Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide)

Supports gubernaculum development during the early transabdominal phase.

INSL3 (Insulin-like 3)

Promotes gubernaculum elongation, aiding descent.

Processus Vaginalis

Provides the pathway through which the testes descend.

Arterial Supply

Venous Drainage

Testicular Artery: From the abdominal aorta.

Pampiniform Plexus: Drains into the testicular veins.

Cremasteric Artery: From the inferior epigastric artery, supplies the cremaster muscle.

Right Testicular Vein: Drains into the inferior vena cava.

Artery of the Vas Deferens: From the superior vesical artery, also contributes to testicular blood supply.

Left Testicular Vein: Drains into the left renal vein.

A 3-year-old unvaccinated child presents with high fever, cough, conjunctivitis, and a maculopapular rash that began on the face and has spread to the trunk and limbs. Oral examination reveals small, white lesions on the buccal mucosa. Which complication is most likely to develop in the acute phase of this illness?
questions.explanation:
Stage

Duration

Symptoms

Incubation Period

10 days (up to 21 days)

Asymptomatic phase; the virus multiplies in the respiratory tract, followed by primary and secondary viremia.

Prodromal Stage

4 days
  • Fever (day 10),
  • Koplik’s spots (day 12),
  • non-specific symptoms (cough, coryza, conjunctivitis).

Eruptive Stage

4 days post fever

The maculopapular rash appears first behind the ears, then spreads to the face, trunk, and limbs, fading in the same order.

Post-measles Stage

Variable

Characterized by weight loss, weakness, and a risk of progressing to chronic conditions.

questions.text: A 52-year-old patient presents with symptoms of indigestion and steatorrhea. Laboratory tests suggest decreased bicarbonate secretion from the pancreas. Which Gastrointestinal hormone is most likely deficient in this patient?

A 35-year-old woman presents with fatigue, muscle weakness, and bone pain for the past several months. She has a history of hypothyroidism and is currently taking levothyroxine. She lives in North India and avoids dairy products. Physical examination reveals mild tenderness over her shins. Laboratory tests reveal: Serum calcium 8.2 mg/dL (normal range: 8.5-10.5 mg/dL) Serum phosphorus 2.0 mg/dL (normal range: 2.5-4.5 mg/dL) Parathyroid hormone (PTH) Elevated Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Biochemical Feature

Explanation

Hypocalcemia

Due to decreased calcium absorption in the intestine.

Hypophosphatemia

Due to decreased phosphate absorption in the intestine and decreased reabsorption of phosphate in the kidneys.

Secondary Hyperparathyroidism

In response to low calcium levels, the parathyroid hormone (PTH) increases, which increases calcium reabsorption from bone and the kidneys.

Elevated Alkaline Phosphatase (ALP)

Due to Increased bone turnover as a result of increased PTH.

25-hydroxy cholecalciferol

Decreased.

Effect

Use

COPD, asthma (often in combination with β2 agonists)

questions.text: Which of the following conditions will not show the presence of nuclei retained in the stratum corneum as a pathological finding?

A 40-year-old male presents to the clinic with muscle weakness, fatigue and occasional palpitations. Laboratory tests reveal serum potassium levels of 2.9 mEq/L. Which of the following syndromes is not a known cause of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Increased Renal Loss
  • Diuretic Use: Loop diuretics (furosemide) and thiazide diuretics can lead to significant potassium loss.
  • Hyperaldosteronism: Conditions like Conn's syndrome increase aldosterone secretion, increasing potassium excretion.

Renal Tubular Disorders
  • Gitelman syndrome(Option B): A genetic disorder causing loss of electrolytes, including potassium.
  • Liddle syndrome (Option A): A genetic condition that increases sodium reabsorption and potassium excretion.
  • Cushing’s Syndrome: Excess cortisol can lead to hypokalemia through its mineralocorticoid effects.

Gastrointestinal Losses
  • Vomiting
  • Diarrhea
  • Laxative Abuse

Decreased potassium Intake
  • Inadequate Dietary Intake
  • Intravenous Fluids: Administration of IV fluids without adequate potassium supplementation can lead to hypokalemia, particularly in hospitalised patients.

Cellular Shift
  • Alkalosis: In metabolic alkalosis, potassium shifts into cells, contributing to hypokalemia.
  • Insulin Administration: Insulin promotes potassium uptake into cells, which can lead to hypokalemia, especially when given in high doses.

Miscellaneous Causes
  • Fanconi Syndrome (Option C): A condition that affects the PCT and can lead to the loss of potassium and other electrolytes.
  • Magnesium Deficiency

Renal hypokalemia includes chloride-responsive metabolic alkalosis
  • Congenital adrenal hyperplasia from 11-β or 17-α-hydroxylase deficiency
  • Renin-secreting tumors
  • Ectopic corticotropin stimulation ectopic adrenocorticotropic hormone syndrome
  • Cushing disease or Cushing syndrome
  • Hereditary glucocorticoid-responsive aldosteronism
  • Hypertensive emergency and malignant hypertension
  • Renovascular hypertension renal artery stenosis

High risk

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents with a 3-day history of high fever, severe headache, and joint pain. Physical examination reveals a maculopapular rash and a positive tourniquet test. Laboratory tests reveal leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, and mildly elevated liver enzymes. Based on the findings, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosing this condition?
questions.explanation:
Uncategorized fever

  • No typical features

Break bone fever

(Classical dengue fever/ acute viral infection)
  • Retro orbital pain
  • Arthralgia
  • Severe myalgia and headache
  • Bimodal presentation of fever:
    • 39-40°C, peaks on days 1-2
    • Resurges: day 5-6
    • Recovery: day 7-10.
  • Rash: pin-point eruptions on the face, neck and chest followed by maculopapular or scarlatiniform on 3rd or 4th day.

Dengue hemorrhagic syndrome
  • Dengue fever + hemorrhagic manifestations(bleeding from any orifice)
  • Rash: Maculopapular/ Rubelliform
  • Lab Diagnosis
    • 20% increase in hematocrit
    • Thrombocytopenia (<1 lac)
  • Clinical diagnosis
    • Tourniquet test- >10 petechiae/ sq inch area

Dengue shock syndrome
  • Pulse pressure - <20 mmHg
  • Mean systolic pressure - <90mmHg: adults, <80 mmHg: children.

questions.text: After a fall from a height with undue arm abduction, the patient presented as shown. Mark the wrong statement about this condition.

options.label: C
options.text: Associated horner syndrome can be seen

options.label: D

questions.explanation:
Feature

Erb’s Paralysis

Klumpke’s Paralysis

Site of Injury
  • Upper trunk of the brachial plexus (Erb’s point)
  • Lower trunk of the brachial plexus (Option D)

Causes of Injury
  • Undue separation of head from the shoulder
  • Birth injury/difficult childbirth
  • During anesthesia
  • Undue abduction of the arm
  • Birth injury

Nerve Roots Involved
  • Mainly C5, partly C6
  • Mainly T1, partly C8 (Option A)

Muscles Paralyzed
  • Biceps brachii
  • Deltoid
  • Brachialis
  • Brachioradialis
  • Partly supraspinatus, infraspinatus, supinator
  • Intrinsic muscles of the hand (T1)
  • Ulnar flexors of the wrist and fingers (C8)

Deformity and Position
  • Arm: Hangs by the side, adducted and medially rotated
  • Forearm: Extended and pronated (Waiter’s tip position)
  • Also known as Policeman tip deformity

 
  • Complete clawing of hand due to hyperextension at the metacarpophalangeal joints and flexion at the interphalangeal joints. (Option B)

Additional Features
  • Sensory loss over lower deltoid.
  • Bird winging effect of scapula.
  • Horner’s syndrome (Option C) if T1 is injured.
  • Vasomotor and trophic changes
  • Cutaneous anesthesia along the ulnar border of the forearm and hand.

questions.text: A child is diagnosed with diphtheria. The child's parent, who is unvaccinated and asymptomatic, is identified as a close contact. What is the MOST appropriate management for the parent?

options.label: A
options.text: Administer a single booster dose of diphtheria toxoid.

options.label: B
options.text: Administer diphtheria antitoxin (DAT) and complete the diphtheria toxoid series.

options.label: C
options.text: Administer prophylactic penicillin or erythromycin only.

options.label: D
options.text: No action is needed since the parent is asymptomatic.

questions.correct_answer: B. Administer diphtheria antitoxin (DAT) and complete the diphtheria toxoid series.
questions.explanation:
Diphtheria Contact

Management

All Contacts

(Option C)
  • Assess for signs and symptoms of diphtheria.
  • Obtain a sample for Corynebacterium diphtheriae culture.
  • Administer prophylactic antibiotics: Penicillin or erythromycin for 7-10 days, stopping if culture results are negative.

Unvaccinated close contact

(Option B)

Administer diphtheria antitoxin (DAT) for immediate passive immunity. Complete the diphtheria toxoid series for long-term active immunity.

Unknown vaccination status or received <3 doses

Complete the diphtheria toxoid series: This includes 3 primary and 2 booster doses.

Received >3 doses, and the last dose was >5 years ago

(Option A)

Administer a single diphtheria toxoid booster dose

Received >3 doses, and the last dose was <5 years ago

The contact should receive the next dose of diphtheria toxoid according to the recommended schedule without needing an additional dose due to the current exposure.

87

questions.text: A 65-year-old bedridden patient presents with a stage III pressure sore on the sacrum. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management approach?
Match the following images with their distinguishing features 1) a) Benign capillary malformation 2) b) Contains eosinophils 3) c) Contains melanocytes 4) d) Contains keratin
questions.explanation:
Condition

Features

Milia
  • A common benign skin condition characterized by small white papular cystic lesions which are superficial benign keratinous cysts, usually 3 mm in size.
  • Predominantly found on the face and nose.

Mongolian Spots/ Dermal melanocytosis
  • Slate-blue, well-defined areas of pigmentation that appear on the buttocks, back, and occasionally other areas of the body.
  • Collection of melanocytes in the deeper layers of the skin.
  • Present in over 50% of Black, Native American, and Asian infants, and sometimes in white infants as well.
  • These benign patches have no known anthropologic significance
  • Usually fades within the first year of life.

Stork bites/ Salmon Patch/ Angel kiss
  • The benign capillary malformation can appear as flat red patches on a newborn's forehead and upper eyelids.
  • Do not need treatment because they are harmless and will fade over time.

Erythema toxicum neonatorum
  • Small, white papules on an erythematous base, contain eosinophils and they develop 1-3 days after birth
  • Benign rash, which typically lasts up to a week
  • Usually found on the face, torso, and limbs.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a three-week history of progressively worsening temporal headaches, jaw pain, and visual disturbances. options.label: B
options.text: It is the most common cause of vasculitis in adults

options.label: C
options.text: It occurs as a result of a B cell-mediated immune response

options.label: D
options.text: It is associated with polymyalgia rheumatica

questions.correct_answer: C. It occurs as a result of a B cell-mediated immune response
questions.explanation:
Epidemiology
  • Most common type of vasculitis in adults (usually >50 years old) (Option B)

Pathophysiology
  • T cell-mediated immune response against vessel wall antigens.
  • Contributions from pro-inflammatory cytokines (particularly TNF) and anti-Endothelial Cell antibodies can be seen.
  • An association with MHC class II haplotypes can be seen.

Features
  • Fever.
  • Anaemia (normocytic normochromic).
  • High ESR.
  • Headaches (most common).
  • Jaw claudication (most specific symptom).
  • Sudden blindness (due to involvement of ophthalmic artery).
  • Associated with polymyalgia rheumatica. (Option D)

Arteries affected
  • Temporal artery (most commonly involved).
  • Vertebral artery.
  • Ophthalmic artery.
  • Aorta (giant cell aortitis).

Treatment
  • High dose corticosteroid
  • Steroid sparing agents
    • Tocilizumab
    • Methotrexate
  • Aspirin may also be used

  • Also known as Contrast-Induced Acute Kidney Injury (AKI).
  • It is defined as an increase in serum creatinine by > 0.5 mg/dL or a > 25% rise from the baseline within 3 days of contrast administration, without any other clear cause.
  • Risk factors:
    • Patients with pre-existing kidney disease.
    • Pre-contrast eGFR < 60 mL/min/1.73 m² indicates higher risk.

Management:

Observation for mild reactions

Management:

  • Mild reactions: Antihistamines (e.g., Diphenhydramine)
  • Severe reactions: Requires epinephrine and advanced airway management as needed.

Management:

Intravenous hydration (e.g., normal saline)

questions.explanation:
Investigation

Key Points

DRE

Physical examination; detects nodules but limited in early-stage

PSA Test

Measures PSA levels; elevated levels suggest cancer

TRUS

Imaging with rectal probe; detects abnormalities

mpMRI

Advanced imaging; superior for staging and capsular spread

Prostate Biopsy

Gold standard for diagnosis; tissue sampling for cancer cells

Gleason

Score

Grade

Components

Cancer

Grade

Description

6

3 + 3

Low-grade

Cells resemble healthy tissue; low likelihood of growth and spread.

7

3 + 4 or 4 + 3

Intermediate-grade

Cells show more variation; moderate risk of growth and spread.

8

4 + 4, 3 + 5, or 5 + 3

High-grade

Cells look very different; higher likelihood of rapid growth and spread.

9 or 10

4 + 5, 5 + 4, or 5 + 5

Very high-grade

Cells are highly aggressive; very likely to grow and spread quickly.

Management Strategy

Key Points

Active Surveillance (Option A ruled out)

For low-risk cases; regular monitoring

Radical Prostatectomy (Option B ruled out)

Surgery for localized cancer; potentially curative

Radiation Therapy

High-energy rays; external or brachytherapy

Hormone Therapy (Option C)

Reduces/block testosterone; for advanced/metastatic cases

Chemotherapy

Systemic drug treatment; for advanced/metastatic cases

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy has been brought to the emergency department with severe vomiting for the past 2 days. He appears dehydrated and lethargic. Laboratory studies reveal: pH: 7.52 pCO2: 38 mmHg HCO3-: 32 mEq/L Na+: 138 mEq/L Cl-: 90 mEq/L Urinary Chloride: 10 mEq/L Which of the following is the MOST appropriate initial treatment for this patient's acid-base disorder?
questions.explanation:
Acid-Base Disorder

Primary Cause

Initial Treatment

Additional Considerations

Metabolic Acidosis

Excess HCO3- loss or H+ retention
  • Treat underlying cause
  • Fluid resuscitation (e.g., normal saline)
  • Start sodium bicarbonate (Option A)
  • Sodium bicarbonate rarely used, only if pH < 7.1 or life-threatening
  • Address electrolyte imbalances after initial resuscitation

Respiratory Acidosis

CO2 retention due to respiratory compromise
  • Assisted ventilation (NIV/IMV)
  • Treat underlying cause

For every 10 mmHg increase in pCO2, there is 4 mEq/L rise in HCO3- (metabolic compensation)

Metabolic Alkalosis (Chloride-Responsive)
  • HCl loss (e.g., vomiting)
  • Urinary chloride < 15 mEq/L
  • Volume repletion with normal saline
  • Most common type
  • Responds to fluid and chloride replacement

Metabolic Alkalosis (Chloride-Resistant)
  • Various endocrine disorders
  • Urinary chloride > 20 mEq/L
  • Treat underlying cause
  • May require specific treatments based on etiology (e.g., spironolactone for Liddle syndrome)
  • Acetazolamide
  • Does not respond to volume repletion alone
  • Requires targeted therapy based on specific diagnosis

Respiratory Alkalosis

CO2 washout due to hyperventilation
  • Treat underlying cause (e.g., fever, sepsis, asthma)
  • Adjust ventilator settings if over ventilated
  • Monitor for hypocalcemia (may cause tetany, seizures)
  • Metabolic compensation occurs over days

questions.text: A health camp was organized to conduct cervical cancer screening in pregnant females. Which of the following best explains this type of screening test?
questions.explanation:
1. Mass Screening (OPTION C)
  • All individuals screened irrespective of high risk.
  • Least efficient type of screening.

2. High-risk screening/ selective screening/ targeted screening

(OPTION A)
  • Only high-risk individuals are screened.
  • Most efficient form of screening.
  • E.g.:
    • Hypertension screening in the elderly.
    • TB screening in lower socio-economic population.
    • Breast cancer screening with a family history of breast cancer.

3. Multiphasic screening
  • Application of 2 or more screening tests in combination to a large number of people at one time to detect a single disease.
  • E.g., Health camps for cervical cancer: Questionnaire, Pap smear, Visual inspection.

4. Multipurpose screening (OPTION D)
  • Screen the population with more than one test done simultaneously to detect more than one disease
  • Screening blood tests of pregnant females (Hb, RA, HIV, VDRL, HbsAg)

5. Opportunistic screening or Case-finding
  • Screening conducted during routine healthcare visits for other reasons
  • Presumptive identification was not raised at the patient's request
  • E.g., Screen everyone above 30 for hypertension

questions.text: Which structure, located in the petrous part of the temporal bone, is responsible for transmitting the facial nerve (VII) and is commonly involved in pathological conditions such as acoustic neuroma affecting the cerebellopontine angle?
questions.explanation:
Anatomy of the Temporal Bone

Segments

1. Tympanic: Forms the external auditory canal (EAC).

2. Mastoid:

  • Contains the mastoid air cell system, which is essential for ventilation and drainage of the middle ear.
  • Includes the antrum, connected to the epitympanum, and surrounded by air cells.

3. Petrous:

  • Most medial part, containing the cochlea, vestibule, semicircular canals and internal auditory canal.
  • Houses the facial nerve (VII) and vestibulocochlear nerve (VIII).

4. Squamous: Flat part of the temporal bone that contributes to the lateral skull wall, providing attachment points for muscles and ligaments.


 

Important associated Structures
  • Cranial Nerves:
    • Facial nerve (VII) and Vestibulocochlear nerve (VIII) passes through the internal auditory canal
    • 9th, 10th, and 11th cranial nerves (glossopharyngeal, vagus, accessory) run through the jugular foramen.
  • Vascular Structures:
    • Jugular bulb and carotid artery run near the petrous portion, making the temporal bone a critical area for surgical considerations.
    • Labyrinthine artery passes through the internal auditory canal
    • Internal Jugular Veins make their way out of the cranium and terminate at the subclavian veins via jugular foramen.
  • Other structures: Internal auditory canal, cochlea, vestibule, semicircular canals, vestibular aqueduct, endolymphatic sac.

Step Process ATP Change
Glycogenolysis Glycogen → Glucose-1-phosphate → Glucose-6-phosphate (no ATP used) +0 ATP
Glycolysis Glucose-6-phosphate → 2 Pyruvate +4 ATP
Energy Consumption ATP used in glycolysis (Phosphofructokinase-1 step) -1 ATP
Anaerobic Conversion 2 Pyruvate → 2 Lactate (No ATP change) 0 ATP
Net ATP Yield   3 ATP

(Option C)

The H wave represents depolarization of the His bundle’s upper part.
 

V Wave:

(Option B)

The V wave represents ventricular depolarization.
 

Intervals in the His Bundle Electrogram
 

P-A Interval
  • The PA interval is the time from the onset of the P wave on the surface ECG to the onset of the A wave on the His bundle electrogram.
  • The PA interval typically ranges from 25 to 55 milliseconds.
 

A-H Interval
  • The A-H interval is the time between the onset of the A wave and the onset of the H wave.
  • Typically ranges from 50 to 120 milliseconds.
  • This interval represents conduction time through the AV node. A prolonged A-H interval suggests AV nodal conduction delay.
 

H-V Interval
  • Typically ranges from 35 to 55 milliseconds.
  • This interval represents conduction time through the His-Purkinje system. A prolonged H-V interval suggests an infranodal conduction delay or block.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male with a history of hyperlipidemia is being managed on a lipid-lowering therapy regimen. His current medications include atorvastatin for cholesterol management. During a follow-up visit, the patient's lipid profile indicates the need for additional triglyceride lowering, and the clinician considers adding a fibrate to his treatment plan. Which of the following fibrate drugs must be avoided in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Gemfibrozil
(Option D)
  • Gemfibrozil effectively lowers plasma TG levels by enhancing breakdown and suppressing hepatic synthesis.
    Gemfibrozil appears to reduce VLDL secretion by the liver.
  • Has CYP action, hence if combined with a statin increases the risk of myopathy

Bezafibrate
(Option C)
  • This second-generation fibric acid derivative is an alternative to gemfibrozil in mixed hyperlipidemias
  • Has the least risk of myopathy.

Fenofibrate
(Option A)
  • This second-generation prodrug fibric acid derivative raises HDL-C and lowers LDL-C more than other fibrates.
  • most suitable fibrate for combining with statins because it minimally affects statin metabolism as it has no CYP action (less risk of myopathy).

Clofibrate
(Option B)
  • Clofibrate is an older fibrate and is less commonly used today.
  • Associated with an increased risk of gallstone formation.
  • All fibrates in general increase the lithogenicity of bile.

Additional information
  • Clofibrate, bezafibrate, and fenofibrate may increase the effects of warfarin.
  • Fibrates are C/I in pregnancy and children. Hepatic and renal dysfunction are relative contraindications.

Cimetidine.

Grapefruit juice (Furano coumarins).

Omeprazole.

Clarithromycin & Ciprofloxacin.

Ketoconazole.

Acute alcoholism.

Erythromycin.

Protease inhibitor (Ritonavir).

Isoniazid (inhibits all CYP enzymes except CYP2E1).

Valproate.

questions.explanation:
Category

Details

Chemical Properties

- Clear, heavy, colorless liquid

- Sweet, non-irritating odor, photosensitive (stored in an amber bottle with thymol preservative)

- Structure of an alkane

- Highly soluble in blood and tissues, hence can cause delayed recovery

Systemic Effects

- Cardiovascular: Myocardial depression, sensitization to catecholamines

- Respiratory: Respiratory depression

- Central Nervous System: General anesthesia, increased cerebral blood flow

Uses

- Induction and maintenance of general anesthesia

- Less commonly used now due to side effect profile

- Still used in some resource-limited settings

Side Effects

- Type 1 Hepatotoxicity: Mild, self-limiting liver injury (20-30% of patients)

- Type 2 Hepatotoxicity (Halothane Hepatitis): Severe, potentially fatal (1 in 35,000 after single exposure)

- Cardiorespiratory instability

- Arrhythmias, especially in children

- Malignant hyperthermia (rare)

Metabolism

- 20-45% metabolized in the liver

- Produces trifluoroacetyl (TFA) protein adducts which are immunogenic and are responsible for causing halothane hepatitis.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman with a 10-year history of poorly controlled hypertension visits your clinic for follow-up. Which calcium channel blockers would be the most appropriate addition to her long-term blood pressure control treatment regimen?
questions.explanation:
Drug

Use

Rationale for Choice

Nifedipine (Option A) Short-acting

Primarily used for angina pectoris

Not recommended for long-term hypertension management due to its short duration of action and potential for reflex tachycardia.

Nicardipine (Option B) Short-acting

Commonly used in the management of hypertensive emergencies and perioperative hypertension or severe hypertension in the intensive care unit.

The short duration of action makes it less suitable for long-term hypertension management.

Clevidipine (Option C) Ultra-short-acting

Very short half-life makes it unsuitable for long-term hypertension management.

Amlodipine (Option D) Long-acting.

Recommended as a first-line or add-on therapy for the long-term management of hypertension

Preferred choice due to its long duration of action (up to 24 hours), once-daily dosing, and effectiveness in lowering blood pressure with good tolerability.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents to the clinic with a persistent cough, shortness of breath, and chest pain for the past month. She is currently on immunosuppressive therapy for an autoimmune condition. A chest CT reveals a solitary pulmonary nodule in the right upper lobe. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Clinical features of cryptococcosis

Respiratory system
  • Cryptococcus typically enters the body via inhalation and can cause pulmonary infection/pneumonitis - primary site of infection
  • Patients may present with cough, pleuritic chest pain, and respiratory distress.
  • Imaging shows a solitary pulmonary nodule
  • Dissemination of pulmonary infection leads to involvement of other organs

Central Nervous System

Meningitis: Characterized by severe headaches, fever, altered mental status, sensory and memory loss, cranial nerve paresis and loss of vision

It is the most serious type of cryptococcal infection

Skin

Cutaneous Cryptococcosis: Causes skin lesions, particularly in immunocompromised patients.

Associated with C.neoformans var neoformans (serotype D)

Other Organs

Liver, spleen, and bones may be involved in disseminated infections

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is diagnosed with a deficiency of hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT) based on genetic testing. Which of the following findings is not typically associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
Lesch-Nyhan syndrome

Cause

Deficiency of hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HPRT)

Inheritance

X-linked recessive

Variants
  • Classic Lesch-Nyhan syndrome: Undetectable HPRT levels.
  • Kelley-Seegmiller syndrome: Partial HPRT deficiency with variable neurological dysfunction.

Clinical Features
  • Self-injurious behaviour: Biting lips, fingers, tongue; begins with tooth eruption.
  • Cognitive impairment: Intellectual disability ranging from mild to severe.
  • Movement disorder: Starts with hypotonia, progresses to dystonia, choreoathetosis, oromandibular dystonia, and inspiratory stridor.
  • Oculomotor apraxia: Difficulty controlling eye movements.
  • Dysarthric speech: Difficulty speaking clearly.

Complications
  • Hyperuricemia: Causes gout and kidney stones.
  • Neurological symptoms: Abnormalities in the dopamine system, reduced dopamine transporters.

Treatment
  • Allopurinol: Reduces uric acid levels and manages hyperuricemia.
  • Symptom management: Controls movement disorders and self-injurious behaviours.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with a smooth, tender swelling in the right lower jaw in relation to tooth caries. A panoramic radiograph shows a well-defined radiolucency around the roots of the lower right first molar. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Ameloblastoma

(Option C)

Dentigerous Cyst

(Option A)

Dental Cyst

(Option B)

Description
  • Arises from dental epithelium, probably from the enamel/ dental lamina.
  • Occurs commonly in the mandible or maxilla, occasionally in the skull base
  • Locally malignant tumor
  • Unilocular cystic swelling arising to the dental epithelium from an unerupted tooth.
  • Common in the lower jaw but can also occur in the upper jaw.
  • Occurs over the crown of an unerupted tooth; commonly seen in relation to premolars or molars.

Occurs under the root of a chronically infected dead erupted tooth.

Clinical Features
  • Painless,
  • Progressively enlarging swelling in the jaw (usually mandible),
  • Smooth and hard, with an intact inner table.
  • Painless,
  • Smooth, hard swelling over the crown of an unerupted tooth,
  • Causes expansion of the outer table of the mandible.
  • Smooth, tender swelling in the jaw related to a caries tooth,
  • Causes expansion of the jaw bone.

Investigations
  • Orthopantomogram (OPG): Honeycomb appearance
  • CT scan
  • Biopsy

Orthopantomogram (OPG): Tooth within the cyst, which is well defined.

Dental Specialty Group, Jbarta" data-hash="" data-license="CC-BY-3.0" data-source="https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:JawCyst_(with_arrows).jpg" data-tags="" height="81" src="https://image.prepladder.com/content/TNVKNTKgdKSF0DBoUa051739248026.png" width="200" />

Orthopantomogram (OPG): Circular radiolucent area in relation to the root of a normally erupted tooth.

Treatment

Segmental resection of mandible or hemimandibulectomy with reconstruction of the mandible.
  • Small cyst: Excision of the cyst.
  • Large cysts: Initial marsupialization followed by excision.
  • Extraction of unerupted tooth.
  • Antibiotics,
  • Drainage or excision of the cyst with extraction of the infected tooth.

Prognosis/Complications

Most common; high risk of avascular necrosis and nonunion.

Transcervical

Intermediate risk of complications.

Fracture at the base of the femoral neck.

Lower risk of avascular necrosis but transitions to extracapsular fractures.

Type

Angle (Pauwels’ Angle)

Type 1

<30°

Most stable, best prognosis.

Type 2

30° - 50°

Moderate stability.

Type 3

>70°

Highly unstable, worst prognosis with high risk of nonunion.

Grade

Fracture Details

Trabecular Alignment

Prognosis

Grade I

Incomplete, valgus-impacted fracture.

Normal trabecular alignment.

Best prognosis.

Grade II

Complete, but without displacement.

Normal trabecular alignment.

Good prognosis with fixation.

Grade III

Complete with partial displacement.

Misalignment between head and acetabulum.

Increased risk of nonunion.

Grade IV

Complete with full displacement.

Trabecular pattern parallel but displaced.

Worst prognosis. High risk of avascular necrosis.

A researcher wants to compare the effectiveness of three different types of exercise programs on reducing blood pressure in individuals with hypertension. Which parametric test is most appropriate for analyzing the data?
questions.explanation:
Parametric Test

Description

Paired Student's t-test

Used to compare means (± SD) in paired data from the same group of individuals before and after an intervention.

Unpaired Student's t-test

Used to compare means (± SD) in two different groups of individuals. The Z-test is a variant of the unpaired Student's t-test used when the sample size is > 30.

ANOVA

Used to compare means (± SD) in more than two different groups of individuals.

Pearson correlation coefficient

Measures the linear association between two variables and can range from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to +1 (perfect positive correlation).

questions.text: A distressed mother brings her 6-month-old son to the emergency. She complains that he has been refusing to feed, vomiting, and passing frequent loose stools for the past 2 days. He also had a bout of convulsions an hour ago. On examination, the baby is lethargic and difficult to wake. Which among his symptoms is not a danger sign?

A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with confusion, tremors, and diaphoresis. He has a long history of chronic alcohol use and has been drinking heavily for the past week. His family reports that he has not eaten well during this time. Upon examination, you note signs of malnutrition and his blood glucose level is found to be 50 mg/dL. Which of the following statements regarding the effects of chronic alcoholism on nutritional deficiencies and blood glucose levels is FALSE?

options.label: A
options.text: Chronic alcohol use can cause vitamin B12 deficiency despite normal blood levels.

options.label: B
options.text: Folate deficiency in alcoholics leads to megaloblastic anemia.

options.label: C
options.text: Chronic alcohol use causes hypoglycemia by increasing the NADH/NAD+ ratio.

options.label: D
options.text: Chronic alcohol use causes hypoglycemia by decreasing the NADH/NAD+ ratio.

questions.correct_answer: D. Chronic alcohol use causes hypoglycemia by decreasing the NADH/NAD+ ratio.
questions.explanation:
Effect Mechanism
Increased NADH/NAD+ Ratio (Option C ruled out) Alcohol metabolism (via alcohol dehydrogenase and aldehyde dehydrogenase) generates excess NADH, disrupting metabolic pathways.
Hypoglycemia (Option C ruled out) Excess NADH inhibits gluconeogenesis, contributing to hypoglycemia. Pyruvate and oxaloacetate are diverted to lactate and malate, depleting gluconeogenic substrates.
Lactic Acidosis Excess NADH promotes pyruvate to lactate conversion.
Vitamin B12 Deficiency (Option A ruled out) Alcohol impairs B12 absorption despite normal blood levels.
Folate Deficiency (Option B ruled out) Alcohol interferes with folate absorption and storage, leading to megaloblastic anemia.

options.text: 200 mg Oral Mifepristone + 25 μg intravaginal misoprostol (4 hourly)

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with complaints of frothy urine, as shown below, and severe generalised oedema. On physical examination, there is marked swelling in the legs and abdomen. Laboratory tests reveal significant proteinuria (3+ on dipstick) and hypoalbuminemia. Which of the following findings can be typically observed in this patient?

options.label: C

Feature

Nephritic Syndrome

Nephrotic Syndrome

Primary Characteristic

Inflammation of glomeruli

Increased permeability of glomerular basement membrane

She reports feeling excessive thirst and has been urinating more frequently than usual. She also mentions occasional fatigue. Her obstetric history includes a previous pregnancy with a baby weighing 4.2 kg at birth. Which of the following tests would you recommend for her?

questions.explanation:
Degrees of perineal tear

Description

First Degree (Option A)

Injury to perineal skin only.

Second Degree (Option B)

Injury to perineum involving perineal body (muscles) but not involving the anal sphincter.

Third Degree (Option C)

Injury to perineum, involving the anal sphincter complex (both external and internal):

  • 3a: <50% of EAS thickness torn
  • 3b: >50% of EAS thickness torn

Injury to perineum involving the anal sphincter complex (EAS and IAS) and anal epithelium.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe neck pain, difficulty swallowing, and fever. A CT scan reveals a deep neck infection that has spread into the mediastinum. Which anatomical space is most likely involved in this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Submental space
  • Deep to upper investing layer of deep cervical fascia, superficial to mylohyoid muscles

Submandibular space
  • Deep to the concerned half of the mandible, between the anterior and posterior bellies of the digastric muscle

Sublingual space
  • Deep to mylohyoid muscles in the floor of the mouth, continuous with the opposite side

Peritonsillar space
  • Part of intrapharyngeal space, around palatine tonsils between pillars of fauces

Parapharyngeal space
  • On either side of the posterolateral aspect of pharynx
  • Medially - superior constrictor of pharynx
  • Laterally - medial pterygoid

Retropharyngeal space
  • Anteriorly - buccopharyngeal fascia of pharynx
  • Posteriorly - prevertebral layer
  • Laterally - carotid sheath
  • Superiorly - cranial base

Pretracheal space
  • Behind pretracheal fascia and infrahyoid muscles, in front of the anterior wall of esophagus.

Retrovisceral space
  • Between the posterior wall of pharynx/esophagus and prevertebral fascia.

Prevertebral space
  • Between prevertebral fascia and vertebral column.

Carotid space
  • Around the contents of carotid sheath, demarcated by parts of investing, pretracheal, and prevertebral layers.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to her healthcare provider with complaints of severe dry mouth following radiation therapy for head and neck cancer. The physician prescribes a directly acting cholinergic drug to stimulate her salivary glands. Which of the following drugs is most appropriate for treating her condition?
questions.explanation:
Amides/Alkaloids

Clinical significance

Pilocarpine
(Option C)

Pilocarpine hydrochloride is used to treat xerostomia that develops after head and neck radiation treatments or that is linked to Sjögren syndrome and impairs their ability to secrete secretions (saliva and lacrimal), used for treatment of angle closure glaucoma.

Cevimeline

Cevimeline primarily stimulates the M1 and M3 receptors.
Compared to pilocarpine, cevimeline may have fewer adverse effects and a long-lasting sialogogic impact on the salivary and lacrimal glands.

Choline esters

 Clinical significance

Acetylcholine

ACh is used topically as a 1% solution into the eye to induce miosis during surgery, while it is rarely administered systemically.

Methacholine (Option D)

Inhaling methacholine can diagnose bronchial airway hyperreactivity in patients without asthma symptoms.

Bethanechol (Option B)

GI and urinary tracts are the main organs affected by bethanechol.
Bethanechol is useful for treating postop urine retention, diabetic autonomic neuropathy, and other chronic hypotonic, myogenic, or neurogenic bladder conditions when the organic blockage is absent. It can also be used to treat insufficient bladder emptying.

Carbachol
(Option A)

Carbachol is injected into the eye as a 0.01% to 3% solution and is used topically in ophthalmology to treat glaucoma and induce miosis during surgery.

questions.text: A 10 year old girl has always loved school but is now struggling academically. Her teacher notes that she confuses similar-looking letters when reading and has trouble decoding words. She often asks for help with reading and feels frustrated with writing tasks. Her writing is messy and often lacks punctuation. Although she can do basic math, she struggles to remember mathematical signs and makes careless calculation errors. Which specific learning disorder is she most likely experiencing?

options.label: A
options.text: Specific learning disorder with impairment in reading

options.label: B
options.text: Specific learning disorder with impairment in written expression

options.label: C
options.text: Specific learning disorder with impairment in mathematics

questions.correct_answer: D. Mixed disorder of scholastic skills
questions.explanation:
Types of Specific Learning Disorders

Specific learning disorder with impairment in reading (Dyslexia)
  • Identified in children aged 7-9 years.
  • Difficulty in recognizing words and sounding out words.
  • Slow, inaccurate reading.
  • Poor comprehension.
  • Difficulties with spelling.

Specific learning disorder with impairment in written expression (Specific Spelling Disorder/ Dysgraphia)
  • Poor writing skills.
  • Poor spelling.
  • Errors in grammar and punctuation.
  • Poor handwriting.

Specific learning disorder with impairment in mathematics (dyscalculia)
  • Identified in children aged 6-10 years.
  • Difficulty learning numerical.
  • Difficulty remembering signs such as +/ –.
  • Slow, inaccurate calculations.
  • Poor linguistic, perceptual, mathematical, and attention skills.

Mixed disorder of scholastic skills

Combined impairment of reading, written expressions, and mathematics.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male fisherman is rescued after being exposed to cold water for several hours. Upon examination, his core body temperature is 29°C (84°F). He shows signs of lethargy, dilated pupils, and a slow heart rate. Which of the following statements about his condition is false?

options.label: A
options.text: Mild hypothermia typically presents with symptoms like shivering and increased muscle tone.

options.label: B
options.text: In moderate hypothermia shivering generally stops as the body temperature approaches 30°C.

options.label: C
options.text: Severe hypothermia can lead to unresponsiveness and increased risk of cardiac dysrhythmias.

options.label: D
options.text: Osborn waves are typically absent in hypothermic patients with temperatures below 28°C.

questions.correct_answer: D. Osborn waves are typically absent in hypothermic patients with temperatures below 28°C.
questions.explanation:
Hypothermia

Definition

Hypothermia is defined as a drop in core body temperature below 35°C, resulting in the failure to maintain homeostasis and affecting all organ systems.

Types
  • Primary Hypothermia: Caused by environmental cold exposure, such as cold air or water. Common in cold geographic areas but can also occur in mild climates.
  • Secondary Hypothermia: Results from conditions that impair heat production or increase heat loss (e.g., trauma, burns, drug overdoses, endocrine disorders, CNS injury, or drug effects).

Clinical Features

Mild Hypothermia (32-35°C / 90-95°F)

(Option A)

  • Symptoms: Hunger, nausea, fatigue, shivering, pale/dry skin, increased muscle tone, blood pressure, heart rate, and respiration.
  • Neurologic symptoms: Cognitive decline, memory impairment, ataxia, dysarthria.
  • Shivering may stop if energy stores are depleted (e.g., malnutrition).
  • Cold-induced diuresis due to peripheral vasoconstriction.

Moderate Hypothermia (28-32°C / 82-90°F)

(Option B)
  • Cognitive decline, lethargy, CNS depression (hyporeflexia, dilated pupils).
  • Shivering stops at 30-32°C.
  • Paradoxical undressing may occur.
  • Increased risk of atrial fibrillation, hypotension, bradycardia, bradypnea.

Severe Hypothermia (<28°C / <82°F)

(Option C)
  • Unresponsiveness, further decline in cerebral blood flow, hypotension, bradycardia, and cardiac output.
  • Risk of atrial, junctional dysrhythmias.
  • Pulmonary congestion, oliguria, and areflexia.
  • Potential for cardiorespiratory failure and death.

ECG Findings
  • Atrial Fibrillation: Most common arrhythmia in hypothermic patients.
  • Bradycardia: Seen in moderate to severe hypothermia, increasing the risk of ventricular arrhythmias.
  • QT Interval Prolongation: Due to slowed impulse conduction through potassium channels.
  • Osborn (J) Waves: Elevated J point, visible on ECG in the precordial leads, with wave height proportional to the degree of hypothermia.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman visits a tropical medicine clinic after returning from a humanitarian trip to sub-Saharan Africa. She reports experiencing intense itching and skin changes. Blood tests reveal the presence of Loa loa microfilariae at a level of 40,000 microfilariae/mL of blood. Which of the following medications is contraindicated in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ivermectin

Mechanism of Action

Ivermectin immobilises affected organisms by inducing a tonic paralysis of the musculature, activating glutamate-gated Cl⁻ channels found only in invertebrates.
 

Therapeutic Uses
  • DOC for onchocerciasis in adults and children ≥5 yrs old.
  • As effective as DEC for controlling lymphatic filariasis.
  • Preferred drug for treating human strongyloidiasis.
  • First-line treatment for cutaneous larva migrans caused by dog or cat hookworms.
  • Option for treating scabies and head lice.

Adverse Effects
  • In filarial infection, causes a Mazzotti-like reaction to dying microfilariae.
  • Risk of permanent disability and encephalopathies in patients with heavy L. loa microfilaria (≥ 30,000 per mm of blood)

Precautions and Contraindications
  • C/I in conditions with an impaired blood-brain barrier, such as African trypanosomiasis and meningitis, due to its effects on GABA receptors.
  • Not approved for children <15 kg, pregnant women, or lactating women.

Drug

Mechanism of Action

Clinical Uses

Other Information

Pyrantel Pamoate

(Option B)

Depolarisation of muscle by opening non-selective cation channels in worms, leading to spastic paralysis.
  • 2nd line drug for Nematodes
  

Piperazine

(Option C)

Opens - GABA-A Cl channel , hyperpolarizes muscle & causes flaccid paralysis.
  • To treat Ascariasis and Enterobius
  • C/I in renal disease and epilepsy.
  • Safe in pregnancy.

Niclosamide

(Option D)

Calcium influx causing spastic muscle paralysis
  • 2nd line drug for cestodes.
  • Used to treat intestinal T. solium infections, especially with suspected neurocysticercosis.
  • C/I in ocular cysticercosis as it causes eye inflammation leading to blindness
